awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  A Next-Generation Computationally Efficient Software for Simulating Additive Manufacturing Processes of Metals
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project is to advance simulation software with high computational speed and efficiency for small-scale manufacturing.  The proposed technology will perform simulations faster (from days to hours) using a fraction of current resources (from clusters to desktop), while still capturing the underlying physics accurately. Such a powerful tool will serve as a platform that facilitates more innovations in the field of additive manufacturing, bringing paradigm changes in part design and material development. This will bring efficiency improvements of 50-100x to many industrial sectors. 

This STTR Phase I project addresses low computational efficiency of existing manufacturing process simulation models due to the finite element analysis (FEA) framework on which the models rely. The proposed innovation consists of three novel concepts: a new FEA framework called additive FEA (AFEA) framework, and two methods called Topologically Conformal Regenerative Discretization (TCRD) and Hybrid Modeling (HM).  The proposed project will advance these techniques for computational simulation of AM processes for metals, engineering them for translation at industrial scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview: A feasibility study of an innovation pertaining to the development of a next generation, ultra-efficient modeling software, called AM-Sim, for simulating the additive manufacturing (AM) processes of metals in order to determine residual stress and part distortion was performed. The currently available commercial software products for AM simulation use a computational framework built on a finite element analysis (FEA) platform with an element deactivation and reactivation technique to simulate mass addition. However, even with the recent multiscale and adaptive meshing approaches, the simulations based on these conventional FEA framework are either extremely inefficient or inaccurate. In this Phase I, the feasibility of the proposed innovation was established for large parts with simple geometries. The focus in Phase II will be on validating it for large parts with complex geometries.  The major outcome of the this STTR Phase I is the release of a developmental version of AM-Sim that can simulate such parts 10 to 20 times faster in simulation speed and smaller in system size than currently available products.

Intellectual Merit: This STTR Phase I project was an attempt to find a solution to an enormous challenge in the field of AM simulation following a non-traditional route. The proposed innovation consists of three novel concepts: a new FEA framework called additive FEA (AFEA) framework, and two methods called Topologically Conformal Regenerative Discretization (TCRD) and Hybrid modeling (HM) built on this framework. The conventional framework with the element deactivation and reactivation technique, although extends FEA platform from the standard non-AM simulation problems with stationary mass to AM simulation problems with substantial mass addition, does not capture the ?additive? notion of the AM process. Instead, the proposed AFEA framework uses a novel formulation that embraces the AM process more closely. Consequently, AFEA framework offers remarkable freedom to implement simulation of innovative methods consistent with the AM process. The proposed TCRD and HM concepts represent two such methods conceptualized by utilizing the remarkable freedom offered by the AFEA framework. These three novel concepts form the core of AM-Sim, and if successfully validated and implemented will bring a transformative advancement to the field of computational simulation of AM processes for metals. Results clearly demonstrated a very large improvement of computational efficiency, in terms of both the simulation speed and system size, by about 10 to 20 times that of currently available products.  

Broader/Commercial Impact: The most remarkable benefit of AM-Sim, compared to those available in the market, will be its ability to perform simulations at a fraction of current simulation time (from days to hours) using a fraction of current resources (from clusters to desktop), while still capturing the underlying physics accurately. Such a powerful tool will serve as a vehicle that facilitates more innovations in the field of AM, bringing paradigm changes in part design and material development. However, the most important impact of AM-Sim will be its role in accelerating the adoption of AM technology by small scale manufacturing industries, possibly leading to a significant revitalization of the manufacturing sector in our nation and the growth of our economy.  


Last Modified: 04/18/2023
Modified by: Ajit Achuthan
